evidence.phenotypeFreeText: never achieved developmental milestones and was also found to be microcephalic at 3 months of age, with a head circumference of 36.5 cm (2nd centile for age and 50th centile for 1.5 months). She had occasional episodes of stiffening and opisthotonic posturing. Multiple EEGs did reveal an encephalopathic background. She was also shown to be cortically blind. At 10 years, she was wheelchair bound, fed by gastro-jejunal tube and completely dependent for all activities of daily living. Physical examination at age 10 years revealed the same dysmorphic features as her sister (Figures 1c and d). She had a head circumference of 41 cm (oo3rd centile and 50th centile for 6 months) and a weight of 20 kg (o3rd centile and 50th centile for 6 years). She also had similar findings on neurological examination, including axial hypotonia with appendicular hypertonia, hyperreflexia and extensor plantar response bilaterally. At 10 years and 9 months of age, she was admitted to the hospital for abdominal pain and irritability of unknown cause, despite extensive investigations. She passed away in hospital shortly after admission.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Mutations of the cystatin B gene (CSTB; OMIM 601145) are known to cause Unverricht-Lundborg disease or progressive myoclonic epilepsy-1A (EPM1A, MIM #254800). Most patients are homozygous for an expanded (>30) dodecamer repeat in the promoter region of CSTB, or are compound heterozygotes for the dodecamer repeat and a point mutation. We report two adolescent sisters born to consanguineous parents of Sri Lankan descent who presented with profound global developmental delay, microcephaly, cortical blindness and axial hypotonia with appendicular hypertonia. Neither sibling ever developed head control, independent sitting or ambulation, and never developed speech. The elder sister had a seizure disorder. Both sisters had profound microcephaly and distinct facial features. On serial brain imaging, they had progressive atrophy of the corpus callosum and supratentorial brain, and diffuse hypomyelination with progressive loss of myelin signal. Exome sequencing revealed both siblings to be homozygous for a c.218dupT (p.His75Serfs*2) mutation in exon 3 of CSTB. The neuroimaging features of our patients are consistent with those observed in Cstb-knockout mice, which supports the hypothesis that disease severity is inversely correlated with the amount of residual functional cystatin B protein.
dc:source.dc:creator: O'Brien A
dc:source.dc:title: Severe neurodegeneration, progressive cerebral volume loss and diffuse hypomyelination associated with a homozygous frameshift mutation in CSTB.

evidence.rdfs:label: O'Brien Patient 2

evidence.dc:description: Adjusted the score to match the original curation's point scale, as this curation was completed before the scoring update.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: head circumference of 34 cm (21.5 SD), which dropped to 22.7 SD at age 3 months and to 24.6 SD at age 1.7 years. Examination at age 6 months revealed axial hypotonia, hyperextension, and valgus position of the feet with normal DTR, eye contact, and no sitting balance. The patient had continuous uncontrolled jerky dystonic movements of the limbs and the mouth. Movement and sleeping disturbances increased over time. Cranial MRI at 14 months was similar to Patient 1 (his brother). At age 2 years, he is able to roll over but his restlessness has worsened.

dc:source.dc:creator: Mancini GM
dc:source.dc:title: CSTB null mutation associated with microcephaly, early developmental delay, and severe dyskinesia.

evidence.rdfs:label: Mancini patient 2

evidence.dc:description: Adjusted the score to match the original curation's point scale, as this curation was completed before the scoring update.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: early feeding and sleeping problems, At age 3 months he presented with microcephaly, developmental delay, and restlessness. The parents re-ported moments of hyperventilation, eye rolling, asymmetric mouth movements, and uncontrolled jerks in the limbs. Epilepsy was suspected and he was treated with sodium valproate without improvement. At the ages of 3 and 4 years, EEGs showed abnormal sleep with multifocal sharp waves and the absence of normal sleep spindles. In the suspicion of epileptic myoclonus, he was treated unsuccessfully with levetiracetam and ethosuximide, later replaced by clobazam and midazolam during peaks of restlessness. At age 2.5 years, he showed a severe developmental delay, insufficient visual contact, and no head or sitting control, reaching for objects, or speech development. He showed an extrapyramidal movement disorder, with dystonic posturing and continuous jerky choreatic movements. interfering with any voluntary motor activity. Deep tendon reflexes (DTRs) were brisk without pathologic reflexes and he was hypotonic. Chewing and swallowing were difficult but he was on an oral diet. He was often constipated. His head circumference was 41.9 cm (25 SD), height 88 cm (21.5 SD), and weight 9,800 g (23.5 SD). Brain MRI at age 2 years showed a simplified gyral pattern compatible with congenital microcephaly, delayed myelination, cerebral atrophy, and mild cerebellar atrophy (figure, A–C). CSF, plasma, and urine analysis of metabolites were normal, including neurotransmitters in CSF. bilateral atrophy of the pigmented irides was noted. the EEG showed generalized polyspikes with a maximum in the parieto-occipital and frontal region at photic stimulation at 12 Hz, at age 7 years.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mancini Patient 1

evidence.dc:description: Adjusted the score to match the original curation's point scale, as this curation was completed before the scoring update.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: never achieved any gross motor, fine motor or language milestones. Microcephaly was noted at 3 months, as her head circumference measured 36 cm (<3rd centile for age and 50th centile for 1 month). At 6 months of age, she developed tonic-clonic seizures, EEGs showed multifocal spikes with diffuse background slowing, consistent with seizure activity and encephalopathy. At 3 years of age, she was found to have cortical blindness, with light perception only. Currently, at age 18 years, she is dependent for all activities of daily living, is wheelchair bound and is fed through a gastro-jejunal tube. Physical examination at age 15 years revealed dysmorphic features including a low anterior hair line, prominent nose, short philtrum, high-arched palate, oligodontia with abnormal positioning of the teeth, as well as a short neck. Her head circumference was 48cm (<<3rd centile for age and 50th centile for 2 years) and her weight was 36 kg (oo3rd centile for age and 50th centile for 10.5 years). She had multiple contractures of her limbs, with significant appendicular rigidity and spasticity, but axial hypotonia. She was hyperreflexic and had bilateral ankle clonus, with extensor plantar response on the left.
evidence.rdfs:label: O'Brien Patient 1

evidence.dc:description: Adjusted the score to match the original curation's point scale, as this curation was completed before the scoring update.

dc:description:
Variants in the CSTB gene have been reported in 4 affected individuals (from 2 families) with autosomal recessive (AR) developmental and epileptic encephalopathy since 2016 (Mancini et al.). Unlike Unverricht – Lundborg disease patients, all of 4 affected individuals do not have repeat expansion variants but have homozygous nonsense variant or homozygous frameshift variant, which is predicted to cause a loss of function of the protein. In summary, there is moderate evidence to support this gene-disease association. While more evidence is needed to establish this relationship definitively, no convincing contradictory evidence has emerged. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Epilepsy Gene Curation Expert Panel by 12/1/2020. As of 8/13/2024, this record underwent administrative updates to edit a typo in the evidence summary. No new evidence has been reviewed or added.

Lumping and Splitting: Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found differences in phenotypic variability between three disease entities: (1) Unverricht – Lundborg syndrome(EPM1) (MONDO:0009698), and (2) developmental and epileptic encephalopathy (MONDO:0100062). Therefore, we have split curations for the disease entities, (1) Unverricht – Lundborg syndrome(EPM1) (MONDO:0009698), and (2) developmental and epileptic encephalopathy (MONDO:0100062).
